title: England netball's new chief executive targets world No 1 spot: 'I want us to be regularly winning the major championships'
text:
England Netball’s new chief executive has targeted becoming the top-ranked nation in the world and insisted the country has “only just scratched the surface” of the sport’s potential.

Fran Connolly was named as the most powerful person in English netball on Wednesday, two months after Joanna Adams announced she would step down from a role she had held since 2015.

That period not only saw England win an historic Commonwealth gold medal, but also increase participation and introduce professionalisation in the domestic Superleague. However, the national team have fluctuated between second and fourth in the world rankings with Australia retaining an iron grip at the top.

Connolly, who has held various positions with the governing body since 2001, says she wants to see England take that No 1 spot while continuing netball’s role as “trailblazers” in women’s sport.

“As a sport we’ve been on an incredible journey and have experienced remarkable success over recent years,” she told Telegraph Sport. “However, I truly believe we’ve only just scratched the surface of the potential that netball has.

“I want us to be the top-ranked netball nation in the world and winning regularly in the major championships that matter: the World Cup and the Commonwealth Games. We’ve started to see that and I want us to be consistent. We no longer just want to get to the final, we want to win it.
description: England Netball’s new chief executive has targeted becoming the top-ranked nation in the world and insisted the country has “only just scratched the surface” of the sport’s potential.
